title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: outlines propose change wildrwolf. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("s3alfisc/wildrwolf", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to wildrwolf
text: Please note wildrwolf project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alexander Fischer. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fischer (2023). wildrwolf: Fast Computation Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values Linear Regression Models. R package version 0.3.3, https://s3alfisc.github.io/wildrwolf/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {wildrwolf: Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for Linear Regression Models},   author = {Alexander Fischer},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.3.3},   url = {https://s3alfisc.github.io/wildrwolf/}, }

what:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
title:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
text: wildrwolf package implements Romano-Wolf multiple-hypothesis-adjusted p-values objects type fixest fixest_multi fixest package via wild cluster bootstrap. current stage, package experimental thoroughly tested. bootstrap-resampling based fwildclusterboot package, wildrwolf usually really fast. package complementary wildwyoung (still work progress), implements multiple hypothesis adjustment method following Westfall Young (1993). Adding support multi-way clustering work progress.

title:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
text: can install development version GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("s3alfisc/wildrwolf")  # from r-universe (windows & mac, compiled R > 4.0 required) install.packages('wildrwolf', repos ='https://s3alfisc.r-universe.dev')

title:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models

Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models

Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
text: procedure S=8 hypotheses, N=1000 observations k %% (1,2) parameters finishes around 5 seconds.
code: if(requireNamespace("microbenchmark")){      microbenchmark::microbenchmark(     "Romano-Wolf" = wildrwolf::rwolf(       models = fit,       param = "X1",        B = 9999,        seed = 23     ),      times = 1   )   # t: seconds #         expr      min       lq     mean   median       uq #  Romano-Wolf 4.834184 4.834184 4.834184 4.834184 4.834184 #       max neval #  4.834184     1    }

what: But does it work? Monte Carlo Experiments
title:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
text: test S = 6 hypotheses generate data Yi, s, g = β0 + β1, sDi + ui, g + ϵi, s Di = 1(Ui>0.5) Ui drawn uniform distribution, ui, g cluster level shock intra-cluster correlation 0.5, idiosyncratic error term drawn multivariate random normal distribution mean 0S covariance matrix ρ ≥ 0. assume β1, s = 0 s. experiment imposes data generating process equation (9) Clarke, Romano Wolf, additional error term ug G = 20 clusters intra-cluster correlation 0.5 N = 1000 observations. can run simulations via run_fwer_sim() function attached package. Holm’s method wildrwolf control family wise error rates, 5 10% significance level.

title:
Fast Computation of Romano-Wolf Corrected p-values for 
       Linear Regression Models
text: comparison, wildrwolf produces following output:
code: library(RStata) # initiate RStata     options("RStata.StataPath" = "\"C:\\Program Files\\Stata17\\StataBE-64\"")     options("RStata.StataVersion" = 17) # save the data set so it can be loaded into STATA write.csv(data, "c:/Users/alexa/Dropbox/rwolf/inst/extdata/readme.csv")  # estimate with stata via Rstata stata_program <- " clear set more off import delimited c:/Users/alexa/Dropbox/rwolf/inst/data/readme.csv set seed 1 rwolf y1 y2 y3 y4, indepvar(x1) controls(x2) reps(9999) " RStata::stata(stata_program, data.out = TRUE)   # Romano-Wolf step-down adjusted p-values #  #  # Independent variable:  x1 # Outcome variables:   y1 y2 y3 y4 # Number of resamples: 9999 #  #  # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ #    Outcome Variable | Model p-value    Resample p-value    Romano-Wolf p-value # --------------------+--------------------------------------------------------- #                  y1 |    0.0000             0.0001              0.0001 #                  y2 |    0.3904             0.3755              0.6070 #                  y3 |    0.0000             0.0001              0.0001 #                  y4 |    0.9586             0.9596              0.9596 # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ models <- feols(c(Y1, Y2, Y3, Y4) ~ X1 + X2                   , data = data, se = "hetero") summary(rwolf(models, param = "X1", B = 9999, seed = 123)) #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |==================                                                    |  25%  |                                                                              |===================================                                   |  50%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75%  |                                                                              |======================================================================| 100% #>   model    Estimate Std. Error    t value      Pr(>|t|) RW Pr(>|t|) #> 1     1   0.9713667 0.03201663   30.33945 9.318861e-144      0.0001 #> 2     2 -0.02689601 0.03050616 -0.8816584     0.3781741      0.6082 #> 3     3   0.3925661 0.03096423   12.67805  2.946569e-34      0.0001 #> 4     4 0.001657765 0.03337464 0.04967138     0.9603942      0.9600

text: n_sims number Monte Carlo iterations. 100 default. rho correlation outcome variables. Vectorized  c(0, 0.25, 0.5, .75) default seed random seed. B number bootstrap draws. 499 default. N number observations. 1000 default. s number dependent variables. 6 default. G number clusters. NULL, clustering. 20 default

title:
Run a MC simulation study on family-wise error rates (FWERs)
for the Holm and Romano & Wolf Methods multiple
hypothesis adjustment methods given true null effects — run_fwer_sim
code: if (FALSE) {  res <- run_fwer_sim(   seed = 123,   n_sims = 1000,   B = 4999,   N = 1000,   s = 10 ) res  }

what: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
text: Function implements Romano-Wolf multiple hypothesis correction procedure objects type fixest_multi (fixest_multi objects created  `fixest::feols()` use `feols()` multiple-estimation interface).  Currently, command restricted two-sided hypotheses one-way  clustered standard errors. wild cluster bootstrap,  null always imposed.

title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
code: rwolf(   models,   param,   B,   R = NULL,   r = 0,   p_val_type = "two-tailed",   weights_type = "rademacher",   seed = NULL,   engine = "R",   nthreads = 1,   bootstrap_type = "fnw11",   ... )

title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
text: models object type fixest_multi list objects  type fixest param regression parameter tested B number bootstrap iterations R Hypothesis Vector giving linear combinations coefficients. Must either NULL vector length `param`.  NULL, vector ones length param. r numeric. Shifts null hypothesis  H0: param = r vs H1: param != r p_val_type Character vector length 1. Type hypothesis test  default "two-tailed". options include "equal-tailed", ">"  (one-sided tests) "<" (two-sided tests). weights_type character function. character string specifies  type bootstrap use: One "rademacher", "mammen", "norm" "webb". Alternatively, type can function(n) drawing  wild bootstrap factors. "rademacher" default.  Rademacher  distribution, number replications B exceeds number possible draw ombinations, 2^(#number clusters), `boottest()` use  possible combination (enumeration). seed Integer. Sets random seed. NULL default. engine wild cluster bootstrap run via fwildclusterboot's R  implementation via WildBootTests.jl? 'R' default.  option 'WildBootTests.jl'. Running bootstrap  WildBootTests.jl might significantly reduce runtime `rwolf()`  complex problems (e.g. problems 500 clusters). nthreads Integer. number threads use running  bootstrap. bootstrap_type Either "11", "13", "31", "33", "fnw11".  "fnw11" default. See `?fwildclusterboot::boottest` details ... additional function values passed bootstrap function.

title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
text: object type `rwolf`

title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
text: Clarke, Romano & Wolf (2019), STATA Journal.  IZA working paper: https://ftp.iza.org/dp12845.pdf

title: Romano-Wolf multiple hypotheses adjusted p-values — rwolf
code: library(fixest) library(wildrwolf)  set.seed(12345)  N <- 1000 X1 <- rnorm(N) Y1 <- 1 + 1 * X1 + rnorm(N) Y2 <- 1 + 0.01 * X1 + rnorm(N) Y3 <- 1 + 0.01 * X1 + rnorm(N) Y4 <- 1 + 0.01 * X1 + rnorm(N)  B <- 999 # intra-cluster correlation of 0 for all clusters cluster <- rep(1:50, N / 50)  data <- data.frame(Y1 = Y1,                     Y2 = Y2,                     Y3 = Y3,                     Y4 = Y4,                    X1 = X1,                     cluster = cluster)  res <- feols(c(Y1, Y2, Y3) ~ X1, data = data, cluster = ~ cluster) res_rwolf <- rwolf(models = res, param = "X1", B = B) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33% #> Error in feols(fml = Y1 ~ 1, data = data, cluster = ~cluster): Argument 'data' must be either: i) a matrix, or ii) a data.frame. #> Problem: it is not a matrix nor a data.frame (instead it is a function). summary(res_rwolf) #> Error in summary(res_rwolf): object 'res_rwolf' not found
